seg.seg: ... (the Sarvapāṣāṇḍika sacrifice is seen coming to an end. Why that? These yāvśi..., ...) Brahmins, wandering religious students, religious mendicants,
(those who left their homes) in ninety-six ways were delighted by (the receiving of alms), (return) each in his own direction.
|| Haima(vati) (say)s: Now, surely the noble Metrak was instructed by the Śuddhāvāsa gods: Having left Bādhari the Brahmin
... (in order to leave his home to go to the Buddha) he will come (from Dakṣiṇāpatha to Madhyadeśa). || Pūrṇaka says: Also these divine
In order to leave his home for the Buddha he will come from Dakṣiṇāpatha to Madhyadeśa. (cf 23)
(kings have come following us. || (Sātagiri) says: Let us go! As King Vaiśravaṇa on Pāṣāṇaka Hill (has given ... order)
(to prepare for the sake of the noble Metrak, let us do the same!) The so noble Metrak will come, so we on our part (let us do) that (because of our wish) to see the Buddha, the teacher! ||
The so noble Maitreya will come. (23)
Haima(vati says: Well) spoken! Let us go away from here! All went away. || The interlude ends. || The (following) part must now be
(understood as) taking place in Dakṣiṇā(patha) ... Then they come, with the noble Metrak in the lead, surrounded by five hundred disciples, with bent
body, Bādhari the Brahmin, (having touched) ... with the hand of Metrak, says: Noble Metrak, I am full of joy, my son, as ... together with a radiant being ...
(already 120 years old), with a worn body too, now with the wish to obtain the excellent immortality, the position of Brahmā,
... I (have arranged the Sarvapāṣāṇḍika sacrifice.) Look here, my son! || In the Etu [tune] || Those who have left their home in ninety-six ways, Brahmins,
wandering religious students, naked pilgrims, religious mendicants, ...-gaveyñ, Ājīvikas, Nigranthas, ascetics living after the mode of cows and given to severe austerities, etc. ...
... to everybody I gave alms. 2. Whoever (was) poor and miserable,
... they go away (free of) poverty. To everyone (I gave) all
... they are full of sympathy for those to be given alms.

p.note: This is not the real beginning of the 1st act. According to the Old Uyghur version, there is a rather long story before this page, cf. MaitrHami 1, leaf 1-6 b onwards (see 3-4). In : b1 onwards we find the same text which in some way may complement our text.
-gaveyñ: 237 suggests restoration to (yo)gaveyñ, “possessor of the science of Yoga”.

This fragment contains part of the first act of the Maitreyasamitināṭaka. An Uy. parallel is MaitrHami I, 6b20-8a1; lines a1-b4 here correlate with : b1-8; the end of the verso side correlates with the beginning of . See also 193-4.
The translation and the following commentary are adapted from 26.
Leaving the house: “to become a monk”.
For Śuddhāvāsa gods cf. Skt. śuddhāvāsa- ‘pure abode’.

Madhyadeśa, a Skt. word, denotes the region between Himālaya in the north and Vindya mountains in the south, Vinaśana in the west and Prayāga in the east. The Chinese pilgrim Fa-xian translated it literally with Zhongguo ‘Middle Region’.
śmaṣ: Sic! The reading is sure, against expected ś_m_a_ṣ (= śmäṣ), as in : b4.
poñś: equivalent to Skt. niṣkrāntāḥ sarve, vide : a5, : b2, : a8, : a7; these are technical terms used in Skt. dramas. praveśakk ār: equivalent to Skt. praveśakaḥ samāptaḥ.
worpu is the correct reading; wopu in : b6 is an error.
This line has been complemented according to MaitrHami 1, 7 b1-2 (cf. 18). 32-33 translates: “with the wish to obtain immortality and the excellent abode of Brahman”.
etwaṃ: three stanzas of 4 x 12 (5/7) syllables. It is remarkable that all names of the tunes are left out in the Uyghur text.
nagni: a sect of Jainism, equivalent to Skt. nagna.
According to MaitrHami 1, 7 b 14 (cf. 18), there are two more works: purāṇa and vyākaraṇa.
